image.altText: A photo of Ola Ouda and Amjad Shehada taken from Facebook.

items.synopsis: Ola Ouda and Amjad Shehada were publicly humiliated when the federal police laid fraud charges against them. When the charges were dropped, it failed to make the headlines.

title.children: Shunned by friends, abused by strangers: The allegations that 'destroyed' a family's life

image.altText: Sophia Smith leaps into a teammates arms

items.synopsis: It's another cracker day of World Cup action, with perennial powerhouse the USWNT beginning their campaign against Vietnam. It's the first of four games on a bumper Saturday.

title.children: Women's World Cup favourites USA made to work for half-time lead over Vietnam

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: When you consider there were predictions of a 9 or 10-0 win for the US before this game, that's a brilliant result for Vietnam. USWNT get the three points, so they'll be somewhat happy, but they have work to do if they're going to win this whole thing.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: FULL-TIME: USA 3 - 0 Vietnam

children.content: When you consider there were predictions of a 9 or 10-0 win for the US before this game, that's a brilliant result for Vietnam.
USWNT get the three points, so they'll be somewhat happy, but they have work to do if they're going to win this whole thing.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lindsey Horan, who has been one of the USA's best, takes the cut-back from Smith, takes her time and plants it in the back of the net with the goalkeeper scrambling to get back. Finally the scoreline is looking a bit more flattering for the US. Smith will deservedly get player of the match for her two goals and an assist, but Horan has been the next best for mine.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 3-0 USA! Horan makes no mistake

children.content: Lindsey Horan, who has been one of the USA's best, takes the cut-back from Smith, takes her time and plants it in the back of the net with the goalkeeper scrambling to get back.
Finally the scoreline is looking a bit more flattering for the US.
Smith will deservedly get player of the match for her two goals and an assist, but Horan has been the next best for mine.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Such a shame for Vietnam who couldn't survive the 11 minutes of added time to keep the score at 1-0. Sophia Smith, who many predicted would be the USA's breakout star of this tournament, has both goals. Vietnam's keeper Trần Thị Kim Thanh has arguably been the star of the show, with a number of spectacular saves. She's been fearless when it comes to throwing her body into the danger zone to stifle chances.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: HALF-TIME: USA 2 - 0 Vietnam

children.content: Such a shame for Vietnam who couldn't survive the 11 minutes of added time to keep the score at 1-0.
, who many predicted would be the USA's breakout star of this tournament, has both goals.
has arguably been the star of the show, with a number of spectacular saves. She's been fearless when it comes to throwing her body into the danger zone to stifle chances.

image.altText: A collation of three photos of soccer players.

items.synopsis: The Dutch team shares concerns over training on a field with a cricket pitch and Mary Earps hits out at Nike over a refusal to sell her jersey.

title.children: Five quick hits — Dutch blow up over training conditions and England keeper hits out at Nike over kit sales

image.altText: A composite image with both an aerial image of the eruption and a woman wearing exercise tights

items.synopsis: As the criminal trial over the deadly Whakaari White Island disaster continues, an emerging line of inquiry is what tourists were told to wear on the day of the eruption.

title.children: 'Cool down those leggings ASAP': Whakaari survivors answer questions on activewear

image.altText: A man in camouflage gear puts his arm around a blonde woman

items.synopsis: While Igor Girkin may never face justice for killing 298 people on MH17, he could soon be jailed in the country that once protected him from prosecution.

title.children: 'They took my husband out under their arms': The man who downed MH17 finally sees his luck run out

image.altText: Rear and side of a Victoria Police divisional van. Taken March 2023

items.synopsis: A 46-year-old Frankston North man who was tasered multiple times and shot with bean bags rounds while being subdued by Victoria Police following a siege on Thursday has died in hospital.

title.children: Man dies in hospital after being tasered by police during siege arrest

image.altText: Daniel Andrews makes a hand gesture at a press conference. He is outdoors

items.synopsis: On Monday, a curtain of silence fell on the Victorian government. On Tuesday, it dropped a bombshell and cancelled the 2026 Commonwealth Games. After a week of backlash, the government remains convinced it made the right call, writes Richard Willingham.

title.children: As Victoria awaits the final bill for scrapping the Commonwealth Games, the glaring costing failure lingers

image.altText: A lady in a colourful coat smiles as she waters plants in a laneway

items.synopsis: Birds chirping, an array of ferns, succulents and creepers intertwined with sticker and graffiti art and the scent of daphne blossoms mixed with coffee: Welcome to Guildford Lane, a vision of what could be replicated across Melbourne.

title.children: How greening permits are bringing a 'breath of fresh air' to Melbourne's gritty laneways

image.altText: Joe Biden standing at a podium wearing a blue suit and the US flag behind him.

items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden announces seven US companies have made voluntary commitments to ensure their AI products are safe before release.

title.children: OpenAI, Google and other AI companies agree to White House safeguards

image.altText: A firefighter works at a site of an administrative building heavily damaged by a Russian missile strike.

items.synopsis: The latest attacks on Ukrainian port cities damaged critical infrastructure and grain terminals. Experts say this latest escalation in the war could have far-reaching impacts on global food security.

title.children: Why is Russia bombing Ukraine ports and threatening Black Sea ships?

image.altText: Steve Smith looks upwards while walking off after being dismissed

items.synopsis: Australia is left praying for two days of rain to save its Ashes hopes at Old Trafford as England preys on the tourists' ever-deepening woes to take control of the series.

title.children: Only rain can save Australia against England at Old Trafford as it spirals toward Ashes reckoning

image.altText: The stern of a very old oil tanker ship, showing rust patches all over the hull.

items.synopsis: For eight years, a rusted tanker carrying more than 1 million barrels of oil has sat neglected in the Red Sea, threatening to cause the world's worst oil-spill disaster. After years of planning, a daring salvage operation is now underway.

title.children: This ship is like a ticking time bomb floating on the Red Sea. Now begins a daring mission to stop it

image.altText: A man looks an an old oil refinery

items.synopsis: Tens of millions of dollars in Rio Tinto’s mining royalties are set to stop in the remote Northern Territory, as clan groups work urgently to cushion the blow.

title.children: 'I'd hate to see them lined up at Centrelink': The end looms for millions of dollars in mining payments

image.altText: At night, a large fire burns down a house on a farm

items.synopsis: Fire agencies are looking to the Northern Hemisphere for an indication of what is ahead and it is prompting them to urge property owners to get ready for bushfires.

title.children: Bushfire threat intensifies in grassy stretches as rural areas dry out

image.altText: A large ancient stone grinding tool that looks like a surfboard-shaped table with two thick legs.

items.synopsis: Analysis of micro-remnants found on a stone grinding tool in Southern Vietnam revealed a range of spices including ginger, nutmeg, and cinnamon.

title.children: Remnants of 2,000-year-old curry shed light on trade routes and role of spices in ancient civilisations

image.altText: A woman in a hot pink bikini behind a bar in a pub, smiling.

items.synopsis: Is the industry really same name, totally different game? The ABC takes a look at how skimpy work has survived in regional Australia.

title.children: How skimpies – or bartenders in bikinis and bras – have survived post #MeToo

image.altText: A man holds a golf ball up to the crowd.

items.synopsis: Travis Smyth nails a hole-in-one on the controversial 17th at Royal Liverpool, as two Australians remain in the realistic hunt to claim the British Open.

title.children: 'A moment I'll never forget': Australian journeyman Smyth hits historic hole-in-one at British Open

image.altText: Image of a man and a woman standing in front of a box.

items.synopsis: The plant-based bio-wrap industry is challenging the dominance of petroleum-based plastics, as consumers become increasingly willing to pay for environmentally friendly alternatives.

title.children: The company turning french fries into eco-friendly cling wrap

image.altText: A humpback whale's tale out of the water in front of high-rise buildings on Hamilton Island.

items.synopsis: The giants of the sea give up their secrets to citizen scientists as tiny microphones capture the songs of humpback whales in the Great Barrier Reef.

title.children: Citizen scientists capture whale songs in the Whitsundays

image.altText: A woman wearing a tracksuit of light blue and green walks on a soccer field with a cameraman behind her

items.synopsis: As one of the best players in the world, Sam Kerr will be crucial for the Matildas to go all the way at the Women's World Cup. And that's the problem, writes Samantha Lewis.

title.children: Schrödinger's striker: How the Sam Kerr paradox affects the Matildas

image.altText: A close-up of an Australian Army patch and an Australian flag patch on an ADF officer's uniform.

items.synopsis: A former Australian soldier tells the Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide that no counselling was offered to staff at the base where a young man was killed during a training drill.

title.children: 'Sent back out to training': Former soldier alleges no counselling offered after fatal accident

image.altText: Turtles in recovery at the Bunbury Dolphin Discovery Centre.

items.synopsis: Baby loggerhead turtles washed ashore after winter storms blew them off course need plenty of TLC before they can get back to their globe-crossing journey to Africa.

title.children: Resistance training, massages are all in the mix to get this lost baby turtle restart its migration

image.altText: a man wearing glasses looking through a pile of papers while sitting at a table

items.synopsis: For decorated public servant Trevor Crawford, the retribution he says he faced after alleging corruption in the Queensland public service drove him to consider taking his own life.

title.children: Decorated public servant Trevor Crawford blew the whistle on alleged government corruption. He says it ended his career

image.altText: two women sit at a table and share a laugh over their laptops

items.synopsis: As we trickle back to our offices, I've witnessed a few of these encounters in lunch spots around the city: workers who are colleagues, but who obviously like each other enough to go and have lunch and shoot the breeze, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: In praise of the 'work wife', who makes going back to the office worthwhile

image.altText: Helen Munnings with her baby boy

items.synopsis: Young mother Helen Munnings was pregnant with her second child when she disappeared without a trace. A coronial inquest failed to shed much light on the case — but 15 years on, Tasmania Police are convinced someone knows something.

title.children: Helen was pregnant when she vanished without a trace. 15 years on, there's $500,000 for anyone with information to help police

image.altText: Hands holding a cut of pork.

items.synopsis: A micro abattoir in Victoria's central highlands gets the local council's green light promising improved animal welfare and a secure supply chain for local farmers.

title.children: Micro abattoir approved in Victoria's Central Highlands

image.altText: Side by side photos of the Treasurer Jim Chalmers looking serious and Michele Bullock, gesturing with her hand mid-speech

items.synopsis: The role of the Reserve Bank in helping frame a debate about the economy — beyond what it can do itself — is a crucial one, particularly if the political debate is stuck in a very narrow set of cliches like "debt and deficit", writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: These lessons from the 1990s should be at the heart of our economic debate

image.altText: A close-up of hands holding a large green and yellow rock

items.synopsis: Gemfields residents heard the tale of a 424-carat sapphire being found, but thought it was a tourism ploy. It turns out the stone is real and the lucky finder has returned to set the record straight.

title.children: The tall but true tale of how a retiree found a $300,000 gemstone in Queensland's Central Highlands

image.altText: Waves churned up after boat charges through ocean

items.synopsis: The Defence Department apologises to soldiers who could be left $15,000 worse off after a special allowance was suddenly scrapped.

title.children: 'Mind-blowing': Soldiers left thousands of dollars out of pocket in pay bungle

image.altText: A farmer harvests rice crop in a paddy field on the outskirts of Guwahati, India.

items.synopsis: India's decision to ban non-basmati white rice exports will spur traders to cancel contracts to sell around 2 million metric tons of the grain, worth $1.4 billion, on the world market, dealers say.

title.children: India curbs rice exports to calm domestic market, global prices expected to rise

image.altText: Man stands in blue background

items.synopsis: Tony Bennett, often hailed as the last of the great saloon singers of the mid-20th century, has died aged 96.

title.children: American singer Tony Bennett remembered as man who 'charmed generations' after death aged 96
